accused.name: Mengeatte femme Jean Lallemand

confession.seduction_context: when angry over losses of animals
sabbat_activities: making hail and directing it where they wished

testimony.quarrel_subject: boundary dispute over hedge between vines; accused's husband encroached by claiming hedge was his

harms_alleged.target: child of wife of Fleurent Bazelaire

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after being late with weekly wood delivery

testimony.quarrel_subject: complained that he never called them godmother or godfather

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after the complaint about not calling them godparents

witnesses.name: Catherine femme du precedent (wife of Fleurent Bazelaire)

testimony.quarrel_subject: refused her some oats she had asked for

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: immediately after Mengeatte came to fetch cream and was close to it

testimony.quarrel_subject: two of his cows were attacked by wolves while she was guarding the herd
testimony.threat_quote: que c'estoit bien peu de cas de cela, et qu'il s'en menoit touttesfois bien mal, mais qu'en bref il verroit bien des aultres choses

harms_alleged.target: two cows attacked by wolves, one died

testimony.quarrel_subject: found her ringing bell at hospital during bad weather, said she had no business to ring and was unworthy
testimony.threat_quote: she would complain to Monsieur l'Escolatre

testimony.quarrel_subject: father quarrelled with her about the load of wood he was supposed to take to the hospital every month

timeline.subject: Mengeatte Lallemande
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Mengeatte Lallemande
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; confessed after torture

timeline.subject: Mengeatte Lallemande
timeline.details: Change de Nancy orders final interrogation; death sentence if she maintains confessions

timeline.subject: Mengeatte Lallemande
timeline.details: Confirmed her own confessions but discharged all those she had accused of being at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: Georgeatte femme Jean Francois de la Bolle
Claudatte (name and husband's name not fully known)
Blaise Francois (deceased first husband)
accomplices_named.context: Accused claimed he was also a witch who went to sabbat with her

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte Lallemande to wife of Fleurent Bazelaire
notable_quotes.french: que comme elle prenoit peine de guerir leur garson, sy pour cela on vouloit dire, qu'elle fut sorciere, que ce luy seroit ung grand reproche
notable_quotes.english: that as she took pains to cure their boy, if for that they wanted to say she was a witch, it would be a great reproach to her
notable_quotes.context: After curing the Bazelaire child using water rituals

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Bazelaire responding to Mengeatte
notable_quotes.french: que ce seroit bien aultre chose sy touttes les personnes qui se meslent d'apporter quelques remede ez maladies d'aultruy, estoient sorcieres
notable_quotes.english: that it would be quite another thing if all the people who meddled in bringing some remedy to the illnesses of others were witches
notable_quotes.context: In response to Mengeatte's concern about being called a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Pierron George (threat from Mengeatte)
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit bien peu de cas de cela, et qu'il s'en menoit touttesfois bien mal, mais qu'en bref il verroit bien des aultres choses
notable_quotes.english: that it was very little matter, and that he was conducting himself very badly about it, but that shortly he would see quite other things
notable_quotes.context: After he called her witch over cows attacked by wolves

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte during interrogation about children's afflictions
notable_quotes.french: que le bon dieu, envoye bien souvent plusieurs afflictions aux humains, et que ce n'est pas a dire que les humains en soient cause
notable_quotes.english: that the good God often sends many afflictions to humans, and that is not to say that humans are the cause
notable_quotes.context: Defending herself against accusations of causing children's deaths

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte about those who blame her
notable_quotes.french: mais, qu'ilz preuvent qu'ainsy soit, et elle aura patience, qu'ilz sont à delivre et elle prise
notable_quotes.english: but let them prove it is so, and she will have patience, that they are free and she is imprisoned
notable_quotes.context: Challenging accusers to prove their claims

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte after torture
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle voit bien qu'elle est desmembrée, qu'on luy appresta a ceste fois une besace, pour aller mendier son pain, plaindant son pauvre marit
notable_quotes.english: that she sees well that she is dismembered, that they prepare for her this time a beggar's sack, to go begging her bread, pitying her poor husband
notable_quotes.context: After being racked twice without confessing

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte about giving powder
notable_quotes.french: mais s'a gardé d'en donner à ses voisins, affin qu'ilz n'ayent occasion de la soubçonner, et la faire prendre
notable_quotes.english: but took care not to give it to her neighbors, so that they would not have occasion to suspect her and have her arrested

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte about sabbat attendees
notable_quotes.french: mais les Gros et Riches, font ce qu'ilz veullent et se mettent en telle guise qu'ils veullent, y en avoit plusieurs desguisés
notable_quotes.english: but the Big and Rich do what they want and put themselves in such guise as they want, there were several disguised
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she couldn't identify all sabbat attendees

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte about Persin's power
notable_quotes.french: n'avoit puissance de la guarir, pour que son Mre Persin y avoit mis la main, et qu'il est par dessus elle, auquel en tout ce qu'il commande, il fault obeyr, aultrement il tourmente les personnes
notable_quotes.english: had no power to cure her, because her Master Persin had put his hand to it, and he is above her, to whom in all that he commands, one must obey, otherwise he torments people
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she couldn't cure Dolemaire's wife despite wanting to

relationships.evidence_text: wife of Jean Thierry, hospitalier du Viel Marche. Had been married to him some 3 years
first husband was Blaise Francois berger de La Bolle, with whom she had been some 20 years
daughter of Henry Chretien and his wife Jacotte
Henry Chretien and his wife Jacotte
The accused, or late husband, had witnessed baptism of one of his sons
Had some vines adjoining those belonging to her husband
when she was guarding the herd of cattle from Viel Marche, two of his cows were attacked
as principal farmer for moictresse de l'hopital was obliged to provide a load of wood each week

economic_context.details: Mengeatte worked as hospitaliere (hospital keeper). Property dispute with Claudon Jean over hedge boundary between vines. Economic tensions evident in quarrels over oats, wood deliveries to hospital. She and her husband worked hard; she claimed to have 'always lived happily' despite being 'personnes de basse estoffe' (low-class people). Her role involved caring for invalids at the hospital, which gave her knowledge of healing remedies.

harms_catalog.harm_description: long illness, unable to use hands and feet; died believing she had bewitched him

harms_catalog.harm_description: strangely ill, always eating, yet with noises in stomach as if a toad were eating his bones; had to eat several times during night

harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft (later cured by Mengeatte with water ritual)

age 10 or 12 when he died; collection of worms
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft (treated with water ritual and barbotine)

harms_catalog.harm_description: started to cry immediately and continued for 6 months until it died, skull seemed to have collapsed
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately after Mengeatte came to fetch cream and was close to it

harms_catalog.harm_description: something jumped on bed at night, witness lost her milk; child covered with small marks which gathered into one large one on thigh; languished miserably for a year and died
attacked by wolves; one died, other saved with difficulty
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: protested to her about this, called her witch when she offered no valid explanation
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed to protect animals while guarding

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost numerous animals, reduced to poverty
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: called her witch after cow incident

harms_catalog.victim_name: animals of Jeanatte femme Colas Colin

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: called her witch for ringing bell at hospital during bad weather, saying she had no business to ring and was unworthy

harms_catalog.harm_description: she threw powder on horse (from confession)
died (confession: Persin persuaded her the wife hated her despite doing her good; she agreed he could harm her)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: mocked her and accused her of being witch (from confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: in extremity of illness (confession: gave her piece of bread with powder while praying she might have as much ill as she suspected her of; done in disdain that she didn't care for her mother during illness but played with other children)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: daughter didn't care for mother during illness
harms_catalog.method_alleged: gave piece of bread with powder

harms_catalog.harm_description: gave powder to beggars; did not know what happened to them

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly rich and complex trial record. Mengeatte Lallemande was a healer/hospitalière who treated the sick using folk remedies including water rituals, herbs, and pilgrimages. She resisted torture twice before confessing. The trial reveals significant tensions between healing and accusations of witchcraft - she complained that helping people cure illnesses resulted in accusations of witchcraft. Multiple witnesses testified about animal losses and children's deaths/illnesses. Economic factors prominent: disputes over property boundaries, oats, wood deliveries, and the catastrophic economic impact of animal deaths (over 1000 francs mentioned). She confessed under torture to being seduced by devil Persin 12 years earlier, attending sabbat twice, using harmful and healing powders, and causing various harms - but notably discharged all sabbat accomplices at final interrogation. Trial shows complex relationship between folk healing practices, community suspicions, and witch prosecution. Executed August 24, 1593.
